awd_titl_txt: Controlled Manufacturing of Lightweight, All-Carbon High Performance Materials Using Low-Cost Solvent Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Materials composed of carbon nanostructures have extraordinary promise for lightweighting, ultra-strength, and high conductivity with diverse applications ranging from active components in rechargeable batteries to reinforced structural composites.  However, macroscopic materials that retain the inherent properties of carbon nanostructures, such as mechanical strength one hundred times greater than steel, thermal properties of diamond, and electrical conduction better than metals, have remained elusive due to required manufacturing precision at the scale of individual carbon nanostructures or molecules to achieve such properties, a scale not achievable with conventional manufacturing.  This award supports fundamental multi-disciplinary research to understand and control the mechanisms behind forming three-dimensional structures of carbon-based materials designed at the molecular level to exhibit tailored mechanical, electrical, thermal, and chemical properties.  The outcome of this effort will be a new large-scale manufacturing approach to enable high throughput, low-cost three-dimensional manufacturing of lightweight next-generation carbon-based materials.  These materials are broadly applicable to diverse areas of structural and energy storage materials, and will specifically be assessed for their performance in batteries capable of replacing gasoline in transportation systems.  This award will support research that directly benefits the US economy and society, while also integrating an educational and outreach component aimed to open a window between the research laboratory and the classroom, stimulate interest in high school students through local outreach programs, and aggressively drive participation from underrepresented and minority students.  

This approach utilizes electrophoretic deposition, a technique using electric fields generated between two conductive electrodes to drive the motion and deposition of carbon nanoparticles dispersed in stable solvents.  This effort is focused on understanding and exploiting the control achievable in this technique to fabricate hybrid assemblies of diverse carbon nanostructures, including graphene, carbon nanotubes, and carbon nanohorns, to enable nanostructure-controlled tunable physical properties.  This focuses on the science behind (i) the development of surfactant free, pristine hybrid carbon nanomaterials from low-cost solvents that have potential for reusability in continuous manufacturing and (ii) the mechanisms governing deposition into three-dimensional structures and on low-cost plastic or insulating materials.  This effort ultimately leads to the development of a roll-to-roll electrophoretic deposition system that can both improve the precision of electrophoretic nanomanufacturing and also seed low-cost, large-scale fabrication processes for functional carbon materials relevant to diverse applications, and specifically next-generation batteries and supercapacitors.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Coatings of nanoscale materials have widespread utility in industry as protective layers on metals, for example, or for device applications such as the coatings of battery electrode materials used to produce lithium-ion batteries.  In this project, the PI and team demonstrated the use of electrophoretic deposition (EPD) as a technique to control the composition and architecture of nanoscale materials in coatings in a manner that can be scaled to roll-to-roll large-scale manufacturing outcomes.  EPD is a well-known manufacturing method in industry for processes such as paint coating on 3-D surfaces, where droplet sizes or particulates in the 1-3000 micron scale are coated onto surfaces.  In this work, our findings demonstrated that nanoscale precision can be obtained in the design and manufacturing of coatings containing nanoscale materials including graphene, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanohorns, and other two-dimensional materials that have thickness at scales near or less than 20 nm (1000x smaller than a human hair).  Further, our results demonstrated a roll-to-roll system with continuous operation that can produce reliable coatings with control of nanoscale morphology at the nanometer scale.  We validated the feasibility of this approach by developing coatings used as battery electrodes that overcame key limitations of current battery manufacturing in terms of (1) cost, by using ethanol as a solvent for manufacturing, and (2) performance, by producing functional coatings at areal loading of 20 mg/cm2, which is 2-4x thicker than electrodes produced commercially for Li-ion batteries. Therefore, our project demonstrated a scalable method that can improve the energy stored and decrease the cost of Li-ion batteries.  Over the course of this project, two graduate students were trained who successfully received their Ph.D. and pursued careers in the manufacturing of battery materials, and six undergraduate students were trained and co-authored journal articles related to the project.  The project led to 13 high impact journal publications, 1 peer-reviewed conference publication, and three additional conference presentations by the PI and students.  This project also supported outreach activities to local middle and high school students in the Nashville metro area through a program the PI organized called “Engineering Explorers,” through the Boy Scouts of America, which engaged students with career paths in engineering and manufacturing topics. 


Last Modified: 12/07/2024
Modified by: Cary Pint
por.por_txt_cntn:
Coatings of nanoscale materials have widespread utility in industry as protective layers on metals, for example, or for device applications such as the coatings of battery electrode materials used to produce lithium-ion batteries. In this project, the PI and team demonstrated the use of electrophoretic deposition (EPD) as a technique to control the composition and architecture of nanoscale materials in coatings in a manner that can be scaled to roll-to-roll large-scale manufacturing outcomes. EPD is a well-known manufacturing method in industry for processes such as paint coating on 3-D surfaces, where droplet sizes or particulates in the 1-3000 micron scale are coated onto surfaces. Over the course of this project, two graduate students were trained who successfully received their Ph.D. and pursued careers in the manufacturing of battery materials, and six undergraduate students were trained and co-authored journal articles related to the project. The project led to 13 high impact journal publications, 1 peer-reviewed conference publication, and three additional conference presentations by the PI and students. This project also supported outreach activities to local middle and high school students in the Nashville metro area through a program the PI organized called Engineering Explorers, through the Boy Scouts of America, which engaged students with career paths in engineering and manufacturing topics.
